shiftman.server

Interface ShiftMan


  • public interface ShiftMan
    Manage a roster for a shop, that is, the assignment of staff for a shop to shifts for a working week. The shop is open for a single continuous period each day, the "working hours". Each day is divided into a number of shifts. A shift is a continuous period of time that has staff assigned to it for the entire period. Each shift has a manager, and zero or more workers. There is a minimum number of workers required for each shift (possibly zero). Shifts with fewer than this number are considered understaffed. Shifts with more than this number are considered overstaffed. Only registered staff can be assigned to a shift.

    Notes

    1. A working week is the days Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, and Sunday (in that order, with exactly those values).
    2. All methods return a string or a list of strings. Some of the strings will indicate the status of the request made to the interface.
    3. If a string is returned and there are no problems, then the string will be empty. Otherwise, the string will begin with "ERROR" followed by a description of what the problem is.
    4. If a list of strings is returned, and there is an error, then the list should contain exactly one string. That string will begin with "ERROR" followed by a description of the problem. For example, if a day of week needs to be provided, but what is provided is "monDay", then the message might be: "ERROR: Day given (monDay) is invalid".
    5. Various methods require shifts to be listed. Except where noted, the format of the shift description is dayofweek"["starttime"-"endtime"]" The day of the week will be included even when there are multiple shifts on the same day in the list. For example, if the worker is assigned the shifts 09:00-12:00 and 14:00-17:00 on Monday and 09:00-12:00 on Friday, then the list will contain the 3 elements Monday[09:00-12:00], Monday[14:00-17:00], Friday[09:00-12:00]
    6. All times are use the format hh:mm (zero-padded, no seconds).
    7. 20190418 Updates marked in blue.
    8. getRosterForDay(String) and getRosterForWorker(String) seem inconsistent as to what to do when there are no relevant shifts. In this case, the list returned is empty—there should be nothing in the list (so don't include shop name, staff member name, etc)..

    • Method Detail

      • addShift

        java.lang.String addShift(java.lang.String dayOfWeek,
                          java.lang.String startTime,
                          java.lang.String endTime,
                          java.lang.String minimumWorkers)
        (1 Mark) Request that the shift specified by the supplied times be added as a shift that staff can be assigned to for the specified day.
        Parameters:
        dayOfWeek - The day the request applies to.
        startTime - The start of the shift.
        endTime - The end of the shift.
        minimumWorkers - The number of workers needed for the shift.
        Returns:
        The status of the request as described in the notes. Possible problems include: the value given for the day of week is invalid (not one of the 7 strings given above), the start time is the same as or after the end time, one or both times are invalid, the shift is not within the working hours, the shift overlaps with an already existing shift. (Change to rule out shifts with no time).

      • assignStaff

        java.lang.String assignStaff(java.lang.String dayOfWeek,
                             java.lang.String startTime,
                             java.lang.String endTime,
                             java.lang.String givenName,
                             java.lang.String familyName,
                             boolean isManager)
        (2 Marks) Request that the staff member specified by the supplied names be assigned to the shift specified by the supplied start and end times
        Parameters:
        dayOfWeek - The day the request applies to.
        startTime - The start of the shift.
        endTime - The end of the shift.
        givenName - The given name of the staff member
        familyName - The family name of the staff member
        isManager - true if the staff member is to be the manager for the shift (and not a worker). Note: This should have been declared of String type, not boolean, to be consistent with the intent of the API. However this will not be changed—it will remain as boolean
        Returns:
        The status of the request as described in the notes.

        Possible problems include: the value given for the day of week is invalid (not one of the 7 strings given above), the start time is after the end time, one or both times are invalid, the specified shift has not been set, the specified staff member is not registered, there is already a staff member assigned as the manager.

      • displayRoster

        java.lang.String displayRoster()
        (0 Marks) Request the current roster in a suitably formatted form.
        Returns:
        A string describing the roster. NOT MARKED This will not be marked. It is provided as an example of how a client might get information from the server, and may be useful for development.

      • getRegisteredStaff

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getRegisteredStaff()
        (1 Mark) Request a list of the names of all registered staff.
        Returns:
        A list of the names of all registered staff. The format of the names is: given name" "family name (there is a single space between the two). The list should be sorted by family name.

      • getRosterForDay

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getRosterForDay(java.lang.String dayOfWeek)
        (2 Marks) Request the roster (who is working when and in what role) for the specfied day.
        Parameters:
        dayOfWeek - The day of the week to provide the roster for.
        Returns:
        A list of strings that describe who is working on what shifts for the specified day and other relevant information.
        • The first entry should have the name of the shop the roster is for.
        • The second entry should have the format: day of week" "working hours, where the format for working hours is starttime"-"endtime. (there is a single space between the two elements).
        • The remaining strings should give the relevant details of each shift.
        • The format for a shift is shift description" "manager description" "worker list
        • The format of the shift description is: dayofweek"["starttime"-"endtime"]" (that is, as described in the notes above).
        • The format of the manager description is: " Manager:" family name", "given name (i.e. family name first). If there is no manager, the format should be "[No manager assigned]". Note: Added closing quote after colon
        • The format of the worker list is "["list of worker names separated by ", ""]" where the worker name format is given name" "family name. The workers should be listed in order of family name. If there are no workers then the format should be "[No workers assigned]".
        The order of the shifts is in the order of day of the week, and then by start time. If there are no such shifts, return an empty list. Empty list is inconsistent with requirement for first two entrys, however the requirement remains that in this case what is returned is an empty list.

        Possible problems include: the day is invalid, no shop name has been given. Note: given the requirements for #newRoster(), it should not be possible for there to be no shop name

      • getRosterForWorker

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getRosterForWorker(java.lang.String workerName)
        (2 Marks) Request the shifts that the staff member with the supplied name is assigned to (i.e not as manager).
        Parameters:
        workerName - The name of the staff member in format: given name" "family name
        Returns:
        a list of strings describing the shifts the staff member is a worker for.
        • The first entry should have the name of the worker with the format family name", "given name (i.e. family name first)
        • The remaining strings are the shifts, one string per shift, using the format described in the notes above.
        The order of the shifts is in the order of day of the week, and then by start time. If there are no such shifts, return an empty list. Empty list is inconsistent with the requirement that the first entry should be the worker's name, however the requirement remains that in this case what is returned is an empty list.

        Possible problems include: the staff member is not registered.

      • getShiftsManagedBy

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getShiftsManagedBy(java.lang.String managerName)
        (1 Mark) Request the shifts that the staff member with the supplied name is the manager for.
        Parameters:
        managerName - The name of the staff member in format: given name" "family name
        Returns:
        a list of strings describing the shifts the staff member is the manager for.
        • The first entry should have the name of the manager with the format family name", "given name (i.e. family name first)
        • The remaining strings are the shifts, one string per shift, using the format described in the notes above.
        The order of the shifts is in the order of day of the week, and then by start time. If there are no such shifts, return an empty list. Empty list is inconsistent with requirement for first two entrys, however the requirement remains that in this case what is returned is an empty list.

        Possible problems include: the staff member is not registered.

      • getUnassignedStaff

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getUnassignedStaff()
        (1 Mark) Request a list of the names of all staff that have not be assigned as either a shift manager or as a worker on any shift.
        Returns:
        A list of the names of all unassigned staff. The format of the names is: given name" "family name (there is a single space between the two). The list should be sorted by family name.

      • newRoster

        java.lang.String newRoster(java.lang.String shopName)
        (0 Marks) Request that a new roster be started for the shop with the supplied name. Any other methods called after a call to this method will apply to the roster created by this method, until the next time this method is called.
        Parameters:
        shopName - The name of the shop the roster is for.
        Returns:
        The status of the request as described in the notes. Possible problems include: The supplied name is null or empty.

        There are no marks specific to this method. If you do not implement this method, you will be limited as to what else you can do.

      • overstaffedShifts

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> overstaffedShifts()
        (1 Mark) Request the shifts that have more workers than are needed.
        Returns:
        A list of strings describing shifts that have more workers than the minimum required, one string describing one shift. The format of the shift description is as described in the notes above. The order of the shifts is in the order of day of the week, and then by start time. If there are no such shifts, return an empty list.

      • registerStaff

        java.lang.String registerStaff(java.lang.String givenname,
                               java.lang.String familyName)
        (1 Mark) Request that a staff member with the supplied name be registered. To simplify the assignment, the (very) unrealistic assumption will be made that both the given and family names are not empty, and that every name is unique (case insensitive).
        Parameters:
        givenname - The given name of the staff member
        familyName - The family name of the staff member
        Returns:
        The status of the request as described in the notes.

        Possible problems include: one or both of the names are empty, or that there is someone with the supplied name (ignoring case) already registered.

      • reportRosterIssues

        java.lang.String reportRosterIssues()
        (0 Marks) Request the current issues with the current roster in a suitably formatted form.
        Returns:
        A string describing the issues.

        NOT MARKED This will not be marked. It is provided as an example of how a client might get information from the server, and may be useful for development.

      • setWorkingHours

        java.lang.String setWorkingHours(java.lang.String dayOfWeek,
                                 java.lang.String startTime,
                                 java.lang.String endTime)
        (1 Mark) Request that the hours for the specified day be as specified by the times supplied, 1 Mark.
        Parameters:
        dayOfWeek - The day the request applies to.
        startTime - The start of the working day.
        endTime - The end of the working day.
        Returns:
        The status of the request as described in the notes. Possible problems include: the value given for the day of week is invalid (must be exactly the same as one of the 7 strings), the start time is the same as or after the end time, one or both times are invalid. (Change to rule out working hours with no time)

      • shiftsWithoutManagers

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> shiftsWithoutManagers()
        (1 Mark) Request the shifts that do not have a manager assigned.
        Returns:
        A list of strings describing shifts that do not have a manager assigned, one string describing one shift. The format of the shift description is as described in the notes above. The order of the shifts is in the order of day of the week, and then by start time. If there are no such shifts, return an empty list.

      • understaffedShifts

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> understaffedShifts()
        (1 Mark) Request the shifts that do not have enough workers assigned.
        Returns:
        A list of strings describing shifts that have fewer workers than the minimum required, one string describing one shift. The format of the shift description is as described in the notes above. The order of the shifts is in the order of day of the week, and then by start time. If there are no such shifts, return an empty list.
